docs.lead_paragraph: The United States may be at the top by most economic measures, but for an important measure of social health -- teenage pregnancy and childbearing -- it moves among the poorest. American teenagers are best compared to those in the Russian federation or in depressed Eastern European countries like Bulgaria, a new study finds. Teenage pregnancy and childbearing rates here are at least four times those in France, Germany and Japan, said researchers from Alan Guttmacher Institute, which researches reproductive health.

headline.main: The Two Worlds of Teenage Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Researchers from Alan Guttmacher Institute find that US is among the worst nations when it comes to teenage pregnancy and childbearing, an important measure of social health; finds that American teenagers are best compared to those in Russian federation or in depressed Eastern European countries like Bulgaria; say that teenage pregnancy and childbearing rates in US are at least four times those in France, Germany and Japan (S)
docs.snippet: The United States may be at the top by most economic measures, but for an important measure of social health -- teenage pregnancy and childbearing -- it moves among the poorest.    American teenagers are best compared to those in the Russian...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a South Carolina public hospital conducted unconstitutional searches when it tested pregnant women's urine for drugs so it could report illegal drug use to the police. The case is an appeal on behalf of 10 women who were arrested as a result of the policy, some while they were still weak and bleeding from childbirth, and who later sued. It presents the Supreme Court a narrow but important aspect of a legal and public policy debate that began in the peak years of the crack epidemic of the 1980's: the extent to which a state may intervene to protect fetal health, and the circumstances under which pregnant women may be held criminally responsible for behavior that endangers their fetuses.

headline.main: Program of Drug-Testing Pregnant Women Draws a Review by the Supreme Court

docs.abstract: Supreme Court will decide whether South Carolina public hospital conducted unconstitutional searches when it tested pregnant women's urine for drugs so it could report illegal drug use to police; case is appeal on behalf of 10 women arrested as result of policy, some while they were still week and bleeding from childbirth; presents court with narrow but important aspect of legal and public policy debate over extent to which state may intervene to protect fetal health, and circumstances under which pregnant women may be held criminally responsible for behavior that endangers their fetuses (M)
